column9: Disability
column10: Integration and Youth. These changes have rationalised the Vote’s structure and reduced the number of programmes from five to two - criminal justice and civil justice. Any review of 2020 must take account of the pandemic and
column11: like the rest of the world
column12: managing the impact of Covid-19 on our staff and business has been a central focus at all levels in the Department and the whole justice sector ever since
column13: perhaps nowhere more so than in the prisons
column14: which the director general will speak to shortly. The management of the pandemic in the Department has been led by the management board and the Covid-19 response management group
column15: supported by our specialist occupational health and safety unit. This work included ensuring business continuity for the public services we provide
column17: onboarding more than 700 new staff over the past two years and safeguarding and supporting all our colleagues
column18: including those serving abroad and those who had to remain in the workplace in front-line and public-facing roles. column20: we succeeded in doing this and much more through the last two years. There was also a significant impact on specific areas of the business. The legislative teams supported colleagues in the Department of Health in drafting legislation and regulations
column21: including the necessary Garda powers. The restrictions on international travel and checks on people arriving into the State meant many dynamic changes for staff of the border management unit at Dublin Airport
column22: including supporting mandatory hotel quarantine. The pandemic impacted the provision of immigration services to our customers
column23: necessitating the temporary extension of immigration permissions through 2020 and 2021. Innovations were also introduced
column24: including the first ever online citizenship ceremony in 2020 and more followed in 2021. Under the Department’s IT strategy
column25: we are investing in developing much-needed digital systems
column26: but the prolonged need to either restrict or stagger staff attendance in offices increased processing times
column27: particularly in some high-volume immigration areas. This situation improved as restrictions lifted and staff could return to offices. We took the opportunity to re-engineer and streamline processes and this has been having a positive effect in recent months. column30: as well as at offices in Cork
column31: Limerick and Rosslare to facilitate those arriving through other ports of entry. This whole-of-government operation has received and processed over 25
column32: 000 people under the EU's temporary protection directive over the last two months. The compassion and professionalism of colleagues involved is a great credit to them and reflects the response of the whole country to Ukraine. Returning to Covid
column33: as the country entered the first lockdown in March 2020
column34: the Department was acutely aware of the huge difficulties and fear that restricting people’s movement could bring to those at risk of domestic abuse. Colleagues quickly developed and implemented an inter-agency plan
column35: including the Still Here public awareness campaign. column36: including through An Garda Síochána’s Operation Faoiseamh. column44: analysis and storage. It represents a very significant investment in our criminal justice system and the future of the Forensic Science Ireland. I will now hand over to Ms McCaffrey.

I think prisons did an incredible job
column2: especially in the first wave
column3: of protecting prisoners and staff in overcrowded congregated settings from what could have been an absolute catastrophe. It came at a significant price
column4: however
column5: and there is an opportunity to learn from that. It is clear from going through all the reports of the Inspector of Prisons that prisoners reported very significant information about how not to get Covid but much less information about what to do if they had it and how that was to be managed. There was a significant mental health impact from the isolation that was necessary
column6: especially in the first wave
column7: including the missing of family visits. There is an opportunity there. I would like to refer to the staff survey that was done in 2021 by the Office of the Inspector of Prisons. The staff recommended in-cell telephones and video calls to improve relationships with family members and to improve mental health. This would have obvious benefits for education and training and access to mental health supports
column8: which is a big problem irrespective of Covid. That recommendation came from the staff. Sometimes one is criticised for providing services to prisoners
column9: but this is a staff recommendation. I want to amplify it from the staff survey. There is an ongoing concern about the mental health impact of the current quarantine experience. Ms McPhillips is aware of that but I want to flag it to her because it will come back. These things can come back in many different ways from a cost perspective to the State. In terms of the directions that were possible under the Act
column10: it was July 2021 before a direction was given. However
column11: the sunset side of things is not clear with regard to unlocking and unwinding the restrictions on exercise and so on. Ms McPhillips is aware of that also but these are the difficulties. We spoke in great detail about Dóchas at the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Justice
column12: but the overcrowding in Dóchas and the refurbishment that is necessary are very significant. There is an ongoing problem about the profile of people there with overwhelming addiction
column14: many of whom should not be there but need to be in supported facilities. I am not sure where the Department is moving and whether sufficient departmental priority is being given to being able to move to that. We have gone through it in detail at the justice committee but I just wanted to highlight it here again. Deputies have talked about the cost to the State of the slopping-out cases. It was €1.5 million in compensation and another €500
column15: 000 in legal costs for in-cell sanitation for 2020 and 2019. It comes with the overcrowding problem. In the Inspector of Prisons report on Arbour Hill
column16: one can see the effect of a doubled-up bunk being in a single cell with a toilet
column17: with no screen between the toilet and the lower bunk. Prisoners report trying to use the toilet on the landing for each other's dignity. These are ongoing very visible and obvious problems that have to be addressed
column18: especially where there are not separate sanitation options. With regard to the priority areas under the regime management plan
column20: there will be work on training as an essential service. That will be prioritised. I want to leave prisons for a second. The money laundering directive came from the EU in 2015. Ms McPhillips said there was a difficulty between July 2017 and 2019 in the transposition of it. Will she clarify that? It was a 2015 directive. It should have been implemented by 2017.

column4: 030 prisoners are accommodated in single cells

column6: 458 share a cell

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	404	They are designed for three.

#BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	405	I acknowledge the work of prison staff
column2: in particular during Covid when we know it was difficult.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	406	Staff have been absolutely incredible.

#BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	407	They really stepped up to the mark.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	408	As have prisoners. To pick up on a point made by Deputy Carroll MacNeill
column2: we are completely cognisant of the impact that success has had on prisoners. Mr. Black and I
column3: and all of the decision makers
column4: met a group of prisoners in our progression unit on Monday - our Red Cross volunteers - who had done a survey to help us better understand the impact of isolation and quarantine on them. We took that away to make sure we have the learnings for the future
column5: but also to look at what we can do now to support people with their mental health. We are looking at group psychology sessions to support people because of the impact of isolation and quarantine
column6: which were absolutely necessary in the context of Covid outbreaks within the prisons but which
column7: regrettably
column8: were quite impactful on people. We are very attuned to that.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	409	Could Ms McCaffrey come back to the committee with projections for the complete end to slopping out within the Irish Prison Service?

column2: we expect the new wing to open in the third quarter of this year and we will certainly come back when we finalise plans on the E block.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	411	Could I ask Ms McPhillips about the planned Policing

column3: briefly
column4: why the Department views it as necessary?

In December 2018
column2: we brought forward an implementation plan and part of it is the Policing
column3: Security and Community Safety Bill.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	413	Okay.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	414	I will expand on the oversight piece of it. The oversight elements that are in place at the moment in all the agencies have been added individually over the years. GSOC was created in approximately 2006 and the Policing Authority in around 2015
column2: so they are piecemeal. The intention of the Bill is to make that coherent. It does not make it much simpler
column3: but it makes the processes more coherent.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	415	One of the intentions of the Bill is to strengthen the independence of GSOC and that is being strongly opposed by An Garda Síochána. The day the Commissioner was before the committee
column2: he seemed to indicate that the Garda is not happy with that. Does Ms McPhillips have any comment in that regard? Is that the situation at the moment? Is there a big pushback against the legislation?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	416	A lot of agencies are affected by the legislation.

#BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	417	I ask specifically about pushback against the legislation from An Garda Síochána.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	418	The Commissioner has a view
column2: which he has given in the context of the pre-legislative scrutiny. We have engaged with him and with the other agencies in that regard. Where the Minister and the Government will land
column3: having taken all those views into account
column4: including the view of the committee when it comes forward with its PLS report
column5: has yet to be determined.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	419	I wish to ask about restorative justice. As I understand it
column2: there is a community-based project in Dublin and one in Tipperary
column3: but it does not seem to be widespread throughout the State. I saw some information in recent days to the effect that there was a spend of €532
column4: 000 on restorative justice in 2020. That would seem to be a very small portion of funding.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	420	We want to do much more in this space.

#BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	421	It seems to be taking a long time. As I recall
column2: Judge Mary Martin promoted this approach a decade ago. It is acknowledged that it is a successful approach to reparation
column3: which is very important for victims
column4: but also in moving people away from reoffending. Why can the process not be accelerated? Ms McCaffrey has a problem with prison space and people have to be doubled up in cells that are not suitable. It would be better if the cells where there is slopping out were empty and we did not have prisoners in them. Most people would agree with that
column5: but because of the pressure for space within the Prison Service
column6: with approximately 3
column7: 500 prisoners
column8: people are being committed to prison who will reoffend. Why are more programmes of restorative justice not being rolled out? It is a benefit
column9: even if we only look at it from a financial position. That is one concern
column10: but reducing crime and antisocial activity and improving community safety should be the big considerations. Why is this process not being driven on more quickly across the State?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	422	I could not agree with you more
column2: Chair
column3: on this. A review of penal policy is nearing completion at the moment and that will set out the guiding principles for our priorities. Restorative justice is one of those priorities and a sparing approach to the use of imprisonment. Prison is a sanction of last resort. You are quite right
column4: Chair
column5: about the need to invest in restorative justice on a consistent basis in terms of its application across the country. Announcing it
column6: as we said earlier-----

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	423	I am sorry for interrupting Ms McPhillips
column2: but the model is working in Tipperary and in other countries. It is frustrating. People are being sent to prison and while I am not advocating locking people up and throwing away the key
column3: the system does not allow for reparation for victims. I recall one case where an individual had robbed four or five different households and they got a number of weeks in prison and then they came out.I remember totting up the amount of money stolen as this detail came out in the court case. Surely it would have been better for the person to repay the money and make reparations to the victims. If the people who had been burgled or assaulted received some compensation from the perpetrator or if there had to have been a restorative justice element of some kind
column4: that would have been better. This has been proven internationally and everyone in the Garda up to the Garda Commissioner knows it. While I do not want to misrepresent him
column5: my understanding is the Garda Commissioner
column6: Drew Harris
column7: wants it. Senior gardaí at all levels believe this is the way to go. Why are we not doing it?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	424	What we are doing is developing it.

#BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	425	It is proven.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	426	I absolutely agree with the Chairman. I could not agree more
column2: but we have to do the work to develop the option to have that provision.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	427	Is it bogged down in bureaucracy?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	428	Where it has worked in Nenagh
column2: County Tipperary
column3: it has been very successful for years. It had a very passionate advocate in Judge Michael Reilly
column4: who initiated it originally. We want to create that kind of provision throughout the country and have that as an option for the courts because ultimately it will be for the court to decide the appropriate sanction. It is absolutely vital in addressing criminality and addressing people's behaviours
column5: surfacing the issue that has caused the criminality in the first place. That is absolutely in our plans and should be coming to fruition over the course of the next few months. I would be happy to come back to the Chairman on that.

column1: #BrianStanley	unknown-#BrianStanley-party	unknown-#BrianStanley-dob	unknown-#BrianStanley-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	429	I would be grateful if Ms McPhillips would because it is something we could-----

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	430	I agree with the Chairman absolutely.

#ColmBurke	unknown-#ColmBurke-party	unknown-#ColmBurke-dob	unknown-#ColmBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	431	I return to the question I asked earlier about the hepatitis C treatment programme. My understanding is there was a particular issue with prisoners needing to be taken from Cork Prison to an outpatient clinic in Cork University Hospital for their care. I had understood it was proposed that all treatment would take place within prisons rather than having to incur the additional cost of taking prisoners to a medical facility. What is the proposed programme for hepatitis C? As it is a 12-week programme
column2: it is an ideal opportunity. There will be significant long-term savings in the cost of medical treatment. What is the proposal for the old prison in Cork? Obviously
column3: there is a maintenance cost associated with a facility not being used. What are the plans for that property now?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	432	I will pick up on the issue of hepatitis C. The intention is that the treatment plan will be devised over an eight-week period and
column2: as the Deputy points out
column3: it will be extremely cost effective in the management of hepatitis C. Based on our discussions with Professor Aiden McCormick
column4: the lead for the national hepatitis C treatment programme
column5: the intention is to have a particular tailored programme for people in prison. The Deputy is quite right. One of the difficulties that bedevils us is we have a population of people in custody whose health status does not compare favourably with the general community. Therefore
column6: taking them out to external secondary services for tertiary care is very costly in terms of the resources we need to assign
column7: in terms of drawing staff away from prison. We are very anxious to develop any clinical services we can provide within the prison. This is one of the services we feel we can pilot successfully
column8: it is hoped in Cork and Limerick
column9: and extend nationally subsequently in a very cost-effective manner.

column1: #ColmBurke	unknown-#ColmBurke-party	unknown-#ColmBurke-dob	unknown-#ColmBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	433	That does not answer my question. Is treatment being provided now within the prison precincts?
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	434	Yes.

#ColmBurke	unknown-#ColmBurke-party	unknown-#ColmBurke-dob	unknown-#ColmBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	435	Will that apply to all prisons in the long term? There is a significant cost saving not only for the prison service but also for the health service. When does Mr. Black expect to have it available in all the prisons?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	436	I do not have a timescale for all the prisons. Our intention is to have both pilots operational this year in Cork and Limerick. They will then be evaluated and
column2: in consultation with our colleagues in the HSE
column3: we will seek to roll that out across prisons throughout the country. We have had this operational through a collaboration between Mountjoy clinical staff
column4: our staff
column5: and the Mater Hospital on an interim basis for a number of years. We are now looking to develop a programme that will be consistent and applied across all closed prisons in the estate.

column1: #ColmBurke	unknown-#ColmBurke-party	unknown-#ColmBurke-dob	unknown-#ColmBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	437	What is the timeline for Cork and Limerick? When does Mr. Black expect the evaluation to take place? Is it likely to take six months or 12 months?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	438	I would imagine we should be able to do that in a six-month time period. Essentially
column2: we just need to agree with our colleagues in the HSE on the treatment plan that will be rolled out for prisoners in those prisons. We ensure the prisoners who require treatment receive that treatment. We evaluate the effectiveness of it in the context of clinical care and in the context of the savings that will accrue both to the prison service in terms of escorts and to the HSE in terms of clogging up its services. I would hope that
column3: early next year
column4: we would seek to roll it out to all our prisons.

column1: #ColmBurke	unknown-#ColmBurke-party	unknown-#ColmBurke-dob	unknown-#ColmBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	439	May I also get an answer on the old Cork prison issue?

column3: so we are not maintaining that building. The accommodation in Cork Prison was the worst quality of accommodation we had within the estate before it was replaced. It is quite expensive to demolish a building. It remains decommissioned
column4: but obviously it is a site that could potentially be used in the future by the Prison Service.

column1: #ColmBurke	unknown-#ColmBurke-party	unknown-#ColmBurke-dob	unknown-#ColmBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	441	I know the building has been decommissioned
column2: but I presume there will still be maintenance and security costs
column3: for instance.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	442	Our fire alarm system
column2: obviously
column3: would still be active because we would have concerns around the risk. The maintenance would be very small because we are not maintaining it for future use.

column2: I have a brief question. In 2020
column3: an issue under the remit of the Department of Justice that came to my attention is funding for the coroner's court. I understand there has been some difficulty with the discharge of bodies

column5: but it is the remit of the Department of Justice as it pertains to Dublin. What measures has the Department been undertaking to deal with that issue in the context
column6: of course
column7: of it being a deeply personal issue for many people? column3: so there can be quite a complicated provision there. I will ask Ms Buckley to comment on this.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-04-28 00:00:00	2020 Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General and Appropriation Accounts	475	There are challenges around this and they became particularly difficult during the pandemic because of the Covid-19 precautions that had to be brought to bear. column2: if I can put it that way
column3: which was really unfortunate. As the Deputy said
column4: one is always conscious of the families involved. One thing involved here is that Covid-19 deaths are natural deaths so unless there was another reason for a post-mortem they would not necessarily have undergone that. The other issue with this
column5: and the Secretary General has mentioned this a few times
column6: is that there are very specialist skills associated with doing post-mortems and so forth. column7: that can increase or decrease the pressure on the Dublin mortuary. We had quite a significant issue in the last few weeks where a couple of hospitals had to stand down
column8: for reasons pertaining to themselves
column9: and the mortuary then took the hit. At one point

column11: when I was briefed on the matter
column12: we had only nine post-mortems outstanding. Effectively
column13: there is currently no backlog of post-mortems in the Dublin mortuary. We have a specialist unit now that is concentrating on the coronial service and the mortuary service. column14: so we probably need to have a look at it. That is very much in our plans for the future. However
column16: I have a dedicated and excellent team working on making sure that the current service is maintained and supporting the Dublin coroner

column18: is not working. Gardaí are under immense pressure and finding it very difficult to deal with gang-related crime
